content.body: no more name=""? a links to id now- nice
Updating this wiki page is proving to be a very time consuming task. The old version was significantly out of date. http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/HTML_vs._XHTML
but hopefully the new format I'm using is a lot more readable than it was before
that is a great resource. Thanks for your work on it.
I appreciate json more every day.
pity it doesn't define error handling, comments, or compatibility with JS Number types, but yes, other than that, it's a nice simple format
I don't think it'd have caught on if it defined error handling
(as anything other than "abort if the input doesn't match this grammar", that is)
that'd be fine too
i have nothing intrinsically against draconian error handling in general
is that not implied?
the one thing that specs generally should try to avoid, is implication
well, s/the// :-)
true enough :)
the RFC does say "A JSON parser MAY accept non-JSON forms or extensions."
that's code for "there's no defined error handling"
I believe that the native JSON object coming in ECMAScript 5 is pretty draconian
ES5's JSON.parse does define error handling, it throws a SyntaxError if the input does not conform to the grammar
yeah, es5's json is better
any good examples of <canvas> art?
http://www.whatwg.org/demos/2008-sept/color/color.html
that I saw (good video by the way)- That video is what got me interested in html5 - any other examples?
http://www.bel.fi/~alankila/plasma.html
good one
plenty more out there
Hixie: JSON purposely doesn't define comments.  They did at first, but people were using them to embed proprietary parsing directives, so they took them out instead.
and made the proprietary directives valid instead? :-)
Nope.  ^_^
"A JSON parser MAY accept non-JSON forms or extensions."
Ok, point.
But they're now explicitly proprietary, with no pretense of being able to be parsed safely by a generic parser.
Unlike the situation with comments, where the structure *would* be parsed by a generic parser, just incorrectly (because it didn't know how to obey the instructions embedded in the comments).
so what you're saying is that they removed both the possibility of comments and the safe extension mechanism at the same time
Yes, precisely.
That was the point - JSON wasn't supposed to ever be extended.

After all, it very purposely is a lowest common denominator.  It includes only things that *every* non-pathological language has and can understand.  Allowing extensions would inevitably lead to complexity creep, and make it difficult/impossible to use as a truly universal data-interechange format.
if it wasn't supposed to ever be extended, why say "A JSON parser MAY accept non-JSON forms or extensions."

Because that's precisely what existed in the wild - parsers that understood non-JSON extensions.  Pretending they didn't exist wouldn't have served any point, but making it so that their extensions would cause a normal JSON parser to abort kept the infection from ever spreading far enough to be a de facto language extension.
Sorry, heading out now; wife wants to play video games.
later

I mean defeat the point of <section>?
I'm kind of curious why the RFC says that myself, seems highly un-Crockfordian
Something tells me most people won't get this "right": http://paulirish.com/2009/bulletproof-font-face-implementation-syntax/
"no final decisions on the content of the W3C spec will be made outside of public-html"  So I guess not on the whatwg list, then, huh?
i guess we'll just have to have a "final decision" to do the same as the whatwg after the whatwg is done :-)
i guess that means the w3c can never be the first one to finish html5

Hixie, isn't specifying things like how to parse a nonnegative integer algorithmically going a little too far?  Couldn't you just give it in some sort of BNF like <*whitespace "+"? 1*digit garbage> and say to return an error if it doesn't match the pattern, and otherwise return the value given by 1*digit parsed as a decimal number?  Actually, I notice you don't seem to use formal grammars anywhere in the spec.
yeah, I always found it intriguing how the HTMLWG thinks it has total authority over the content of the spec and is entitled to such privliges, despite supposedly working with the WHATWG
Formal grammars are just as precise as algorithms, and typically easier to read, so unless they can't meet HTML 5's error-handling requirements, I don't see why algorithms would be preferred.
AryehGregor: a grammar doesn't tell you how to interpret the value, only how to check if it's valid or not.

I was actually trying to implement the real number parsing in PHP for MediaWiki (to ensure consistent client-/server-side parsing of <input type=number>), but gave up because the algorithm given is ridiculous in a language like PHP and the only sane thing to do was try to convert it to regex.
Hixie, it breaks it into pieces for you, and you can then assign meaning to the pieces.
In this case, "parse the 1*digit bit as a decimal integer, and ignore the rest".
you aren't supposed to implement the algorithms line for line
translate the algorithms into whatever is the most optimal implementation for your language
AryehGregor: then you're using algorithm _and_ a grammar
AryehGregor: and the spec becomes very inconsistent, sing grammars in the simple cases, and  n the others
Part of the algorithm is just "parse this using BNF", which is already well-understood.  Rely on existing standards and all that.
I think some letters got dropped from your last line.
hold on computer issues

In my case the usual way to do it would be regex, which is a lot closer to BNF than the C-style algorithm you give.  I should think it would be easier to translate from BNF into a C-style algorithm than the reverse.
did you try writing something out?
In cases like the HTML parser you probably really can't use BNF because you need to specify error-handling and such in so much detail.
you need to specify error-handling in detail everywhere...
ok where was i

annevk3, I tried briefly.  To be honest, in the end I mostly gave up because I didn't want to use it unless I had a test suite that would confirm I didn't botch things much.  I'm sure I'll return to it and figure it out, but most specs use BNF and it seems both shorter and easier to read to me, and no less precise.
i was saying that if you use algorithms everywhere but some of them also use a grammar, you end up with an inconsistent style
annevk3, for things like parsing a non-negative integer there's no error handling except "return an error if it's invalid", which BNF is fine at.
and worse, maintenance becomes a nightmare
because sometimes (often!) things get more complicated
and so you then suddenly find yourself having to expand what was an algorithm that used a grammar into something without a grammar
Hmm.
Okay, that makes sense.

isn't a big fan of formal grammars because for anything but the simplest of syntaxes, they simply aren't readable, nor do they actually define the semantics, nor do they make error handling even remotely sane to specify
Well, I was specifically referring to really simple syntaxes.  :)

Lachy: well that's not good. file a bug.

also describe that the attributes xlink:actuate, xlink:arcrole, xlink:href, xlink:role, xlink:show, xlink:title, xlink:type, xml:base, xml:lang and xml:space can be used on foreign elements and must use those prefixes

<nav> is like a special kind of <section>

go ahead
you all are as welcome to close bugs as i am
really? I thought you were meant to do it. But ok

That seems odd to me, because I never thought of <nav> as a type of section. It confused me when I tried the outliner last night (I thought the untitled section had something to do with an <article>).
it's the wg bug system
not mine :-)
da3d: <nav>, <aside>, <section>, <article>

s/and/any/
or mark duplicates

Hixie: Might just be my odd expectations then, I just think <nav> is a bit odd to include in that group :)
why?
i mean, it's a section, no? how is <nav> different from <aside> or <section>?
I don't expect navbars to generally need or contain headings.
I very much expect all <section>, <article> and <aside> to have at least one heading.
i expect a lot of <section> and <aside>s to not have headings
e.g. consider gmail; the main inbox is a <section>, the search area is a <section>, the chat box is an <aside>...
no headers
I'd consider that to be generally bad authoring (unless it's an <aside> pull-out quote or something). Web apps like Gmail might be a bit different, but I'd at least some of those to have headings.
some, sure
most, maybe, even

Maybe it would help if the outliner generated default implied headings for sectioning elements like <nav>. Something like "Untitled Navigation Section", or simply "Navigation". I don't think this really needs to be defined though, just an implementation feature.
yeah
good idea
maybe an informative note in the spec about that for implementations might be useful
file a bug :-)
I agree with that. I think a whole lot of people will be scratching their head at those untitled sections otherwise (like I did last night) :-)
Unrelated question: Would it be considered odd/wrong/bad (in terms of semantics) to have a <footer>, but no <header>?

and since the spec says to execute the first relevant step, once a heading content element is at the top of the stack, then the rest of the steps are irrelevant

+-- Heading C

TabAtkins, numerical methods are useless on the general three-body problem.  Some solutions are chaotic.  Any finite-precision numerical method will give you useless results for those cases.
On the other hand, there's totally a supercomputer in the other room...
(AFAIK)

No, it's not uncomputable.
You can compute the doubling time for errors.
Of course, in the chaotic cases, your input data is worthless, so no solution is useful.

That's the most important measure of code.  Once a function gets longer than a screen, it's time to refactor.  You can't really *understand* a function that you can't see all at once.

If you would like, you can use "head" as a unit of measurement.  If your code is bigger than your head (pressed against the screen), it needs to be refactored.  It amounts to roughly the same thing.

By using a unit of measurement that is inherently personal, it personalizes the rule.
It also doesn't require counting.
gsnedders: who did you talk to at soton, ooi?

You can't really talk about how many screens long a program is, after all.  It just doesn't make much sense.  But saying "each function should fit on the screen" promotes the ideal of refactoring and splitting out subfunctions rather than duplicating code.

$ wget -qO- --user-agent=Simetrical http://www.wikipedia.org | head -n 1
<!doctype html>
We need bugs 640 and 641 fixed in the validator . . . http://validator.nu/?doc=http://www.wikipedia.org

prefers <!DOCTYPE html>
uses the lowercase form, because it's less effort to type
nonsense.  uppercase letters are the devil.
gsnedders: How is it less effort? You have to hold down the shift key for <!, and you just keep it down a bit longer
Of course, www.wikipedia.org is kind of trivial, since it's just a static HTML page.
Converting en.wikipedia.org is more interesting.  I have no idea when the next software deployment will be.
AryehGregor: Is there any change on www. other than the doctype?
$ gzip < /tmp/wp.html > /tmp/wp1.html.gz
$ sed 's/<!doctype/<!DOCTYPE/' < /tmp/wp.html | gzip > /tmp/wp2.html.gz
$ ls -l /tmp/wp*
-rw-r--r-- 1 aryeh aryeh 12004 2009-09-06 12:51 /tmp/wp1.html.gz
-rw-r--r-- 1 aryeh aryeh 12007 2009-09-06 12:51 /tmp/wp2.html.gz
-rw-r--r-- 1 aryeh aryeh 46418 2009-09-06 12:50 /tmp/wp.html
<!doctype is three bytes shorter than <!DOCTYPE when gzipped.  I rest my case.
Philip`, yeah, a few trivial things like removing <big>.
And dropping type="text/css" and such.
The wiki itself will be deploying a few actual features, like HTML 5 <input>.
But not many.  There aren't many new HTML 5 features that are usable in practice yet for authors.
Suggestions are welcome.
http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/HTML_5 <-- Add here if you like.
AryehGregor: Is it still shorter if you have a title containing DOCTYPE again right afterwards?
Dashiva, doubtful.
Really doubtful if you have a few.
But maybe.
What if you use <!Doctype>?
The reason is that there tend to be a lot more lowercase letters in English text than uppercase.
So lowercase strings get compressed better.
I'll be happy when the openid patch gets integratd.
Philip`, 12005, so still a byte larger.
